description-en: On this calender from 1930 from the soap manufacturer Erasmic, a couple dressed in richly embroidered clothes can be seen in a palace like surrounding. The man holds a box of soap in his hands and looks toward the woman who holds a flower garland in her hands. A table in the foreground holds a container of perfume and other products by Erasmic. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: More striking than the romanticized Orient evoked in this calendar selling Erasmic soap and perfumes (which begs the question about whom this was actually meant for!) is the allusion to diverse transnational constituencies. With text describing its high quality product in Urdu, Gujarati, Tamil, Burmese and Sinhala, the calendar was clearly meant to travel to other British colonies in the subcontinent. The use of all these texts acquires greater significance if we look at the histories and journeys of languages through trans-border migrations and indentured labour. (Sabeena Gadihoke)(gs)
